Which of the following threads are used for power screw?
choices: Square thread, Acme thread, & Unified thread
Acme thread, Unified thread, & Buttress thread
Square thread, Unified thread, & Acme thread
Square thread, Acme thread, & Buttress Thread
answer: Square thread, Acme thread, & Buttress Thread

question: A bearing lubrication obtained by introducing the lubricant, which is sometimes air or water, into the load-bearing area at a pressure high enough to separate the surfaces with a relatively thick film of lubricant. This lubrication does not require motion of one surface relative to another.
An externally threaded fastener intended to be used with a nut is said to be a:
It is a lubrication condition where non-conformal surfaces are completely separated by lubricant film and no asperities are in contact.
These springs are made from one or more flat strips of brass, bronze, steel or other materials loaded as cantilevers or simple beams.
This refers to the space between adjacent coils when the spring is compressed to its operating length.

This material is the most popular alloy spring steel for conditions involving higher stresses than can be used with the high-carbon steels and for use where fatigue resistance and long endurance are needed; this is also good for shock and impact loads.
For an American Standard Screw Threads, what does 6-32 UNC designate?
choices: Size 6, 32 threads per inch, coarse thread
6 inches basic diameter, 32 threads per inch, coarse
Size 6, 32 threads per inch, fine thread
32 inches basic diameter, 6 threads per inch, coarse
answer: Size 6, 32 threads per inch, coarse thread

question: It is a Grashof four-bar mechanism in which the shortest link is the frame or fixed link and the other two cranks completely rotate with their axes. How do you call this Grashof four-bar mechanism?

For a planar four-bar linkage, the sum of the shortest and longest lengths cannot be greater than the sum of the remaining two link lengths if there is to be a continuous relative rotation between two members. How do you call the preceding statement?
Which of the following is not true for an instant center or centro of planar linkages?
choices: Centro is a point common to two bodies having the same velocity in each.
Centro is a point in one body about which another body does not rotate.
Centro is a point in one body about which another body actually turns.
Centro is a point in one body about which another body tends to turn.
answer: Centro is a point in one body about which another body does not rotate.

question: This is the most common work holding device of a shaper machine with the base graduated in degrees that make it possible to swivel any angle. What is this working device?
choices: Parallel bars and hold down bars

question: This is a shaper operation, which is shaping the given stock and having the excess material remain with a tolerable allowance for finishing. How do you call this operation?
How do you call a cutting tool that has two or more cutting edges as in drill presses and milling machine cutters?

It is called as the transformation of concepts and ideas into useful machinery. What is this?
This is a combination of mechanisms and other components that transforms, transmits, or uses energy, load, or motion for a specific purpose. How do you call this?

How do you call the strain energy per unit volume required to stress a material from an unloaded state to the point of yielding?
What is the ability of the material to absorb energy up to fracture?
What is the other term for the Maximum-Shear-Stress Theory, as a failure prediction theory?

This is a theory in cyclic and impact loading, which states that damage at any stress level is proportional to the number of cycles. What is this theory commonly called?

How do you call the speed at which a rotating shaft becomes dynamically unstable?

What is a set of specifications for parts, materials, or processes intended to achieve uniformity, efficiency, and a specified quality?

What is the algebraic difference between a size and the corresponding basic size?
What is the difference between the maximum and minimum size limits of a part?
What are the stated maximum and minimum dimensions?
This is a general term that refers to the mating of cylindrical parts such as a bolt or a hole; it is used only when the internal member is smaller than the external member. How do you call this?

What do you call a material having different properties in all directions at a point in solid?

It is the condition of a machine element when it is completely inoperable, cannot perform its intended function adequately, or is unreliable for continued safe use. What do you call this condition?
How do you call a statistical data used to identify the most likely failure modes?

It is a computational method used for solving complex shapes, such as those found in machinery; replaces the complex shape with a set of simple elements interconnected at a finite set of a specific purpose. What is this computational method?

It is a beam where one end is fixed and the other end is free. How do you call this beam?

How do you call a type of welding where the arc is covered with a welding composition and a bare electrode wire is fed automatically?
